hints_html:
First, try drawing a picture, complete with intersection points.

Then use the method of cylindrical shells.
hints_latex: First, try drawing a picture, complete with intersection points.
Then use the method of cylindrical shells.
hints_raw:
First, try drawing a picture, complete with intersection points.
Then use the method of cylindrical shells.
question: 2 (d)
sols_html:
First, we draw a picture. Setting the line and parabola equal to each other, we see that the points of intersection are at

\[\begin{aligned} (x-2)^{2} &= x \\ x^{2} - 4x +4 &= x \\ x^{2} - 5x +4 &= 0 \\ (x-4)(x-1) &= 0\end{aligned}\]

and so x=1 or x=4. This gives the following picture.

The white area is what we want to rotate. Let x be a point between 1 and 4. Then the radius of a shell is r = 5-x. The height of a shell is \(h = x-(x-2)^{2}\). Thus, when we rotate about x=5, the height will move a distance of \(2\pi r\) and hence, the volume of revolution is

\[\begin{aligned} V &= \int_{1}^{4}2\pi(5-x)(x-(x-2)^{2})\,dx \\ &= \int_{1}^{4}2\pi(5-x)(x-x^{2} + 4x - 4)\,dx \\ &= \int_{1}^{4}2\pi(5-x)(-x^{2} + 5x - 4)\,dx \\ &= \int_{1}^{4}2\pi(5(-x^{2} + 5x - 4) -x(-x^{2} + 5x - 4))\,dx \\ &= \int_{1}^{4}2\pi(-5x^{2} + 25x - 20 +x^{3} - 5x^{2} + 4x)\,dx \\ &= \int_{1}^{4}2\pi(x^{3} -10x^{2} + 29x - 20) \,dx \\ &= 2\pi(x^{4}/4 -10x^{3}/3 + 29x^{2}/2 - 20x)\bigg|_{1}^{4} \\ &= 2\pi(4^{4}/4 -10(4)^{3}/3 + 29(4)^{2}/2 - 20(4) \\ & \quad - ((1)^{4}/4 -10(1)^{3}/3 + 29(1)^{2}/2 - 20(1)))\\ &= 2\pi(64 -640/3 + 29(8) - 80 - (1/4 -10/3 + 29/2 - 20))\\ &= 45\pi/2\end{aligned}\]
sols_latex:
First, we draw a picture. Setting the line and parabola equal to each
other, we see that the points of intersection are at

\begin{align*}
(x-2)^{2} &= x \\
x^{2} - 4x +4 &= x \\
x^{2} - 5x +4 &= 0 \\
(x-4)(x-1) &= 0
\end{align*}

and so \emph{x}=1 or \emph{x}=4. This gives the following picture.

\begin{description}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item[]
\includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{../json_data/MATH101/April_2006/MATH1012006Q2d.jpg}
\end{description}

The white area is what we want to rotate. Let \emph{x} be a point
between 1 and 4. Then the radius of a shell is \emph{r} = 5-\emph{x}.
The height of a shell is $h = x-(x-2)^{2}$. Thus, when we rotate about
\emph{x}=5, the height will move a distance of $2\pi r$ and hence, the
volume of revolution is

\begin{align*}
V &= \int_{1}^{4}2\pi(5-x)(x-(x-2)^{2})\,dx \\
&= \int_{1}^{4}2\pi(5-x)(x-x^{2} + 4x - 4)\,dx \\
&= \int_{1}^{4}2\pi(5-x)(-x^{2} + 5x - 4)\,dx \\
&= \int_{1}^{4}2\pi(5(-x^{2} + 5x - 4) -x(-x^{2} + 5x - 4))\,dx \\
&= \int_{1}^{4}2\pi(-5x^{2} + 25x - 20 +x^{3} - 5x^{2} + 4x)\,dx \\
&= \int_{1}^{4}2\pi(x^{3} -10x^{2} + 29x - 20) \,dx \\
&= 2\pi(x^{4}/4 -10x^{3}/3 + 29x^{2}/2 - 20x)\bigg|_{1}^{4} \\
&= 2\pi(4^{4}/4 -10(4)^{3}/3 + 29(4)^{2}/2 - 20(4) \\
& \quad - ((1)^{4}/4 -10(1)^{3}/3 + 29(1)^{2}/2 - 20(1)))\\
&= 2\pi(64 -640/3 + 29(8) - 80 - (1/4 -10/3 + 29/2 - 20))\\
&= 45\pi/2
\end{align*}
sols_raw:
First, we draw a picture. Setting the line and parabola equal to each other, we see that the points of intersection are at

:<math>
\begin{align}
(x-2)^{2} &= x \\
x^{2} - 4x +4 &= x \\
x^{2} - 5x +4 &= 0 \\
(x-4)(x-1) &= 0
\end{align}
</math>

and so ''x''=1 or ''x''=4. This gives the following picture.

:[[File:MATH1012006Q2d.jpg]]

The white area is what we want to rotate. Let ''x'' be a point between 1 and 4. Then the radius of a shell is ''r'' = 5-''x''. The height of a shell is <math> h = x-(x-2)^{2} </math>. Thus, when we rotate about ''x''=5, the height will move a distance of <math> 2\pi r</math> and hence, the volume of revolution is

:<math>
\begin{align}
V &= \int_{1}^{4}2\pi(5-x)(x-(x-2)^{2})\,dx \\
&= \int_{1}^{4}2\pi(5-x)(x-x^{2} + 4x - 4)\,dx \\
&= \int_{1}^{4}2\pi(5-x)(-x^{2} + 5x - 4)\,dx \\
&= \int_{1}^{4}2\pi(5(-x^{2} + 5x - 4) -x(-x^{2} + 5x - 4))\,dx \\
&= \int_{1}^{4}2\pi(-5x^{2} + 25x - 20 +x^{3} - 5x^{2} + 4x)\,dx \\
&= \int_{1}^{4}2\pi(x^{3} -10x^{2} + 29x - 20) \,dx \\
&= 2\pi(x^{4}/4 -10x^{3}/3 + 29x^{2}/2 - 20x)\bigg|_{1}^{4} \\
&= 2\pi(4^{4}/4 -10(4)^{3}/3 + 29(4)^{2}/2 - 20(4) \\
& \quad - ((1)^{4}/4 -10(1)^{3}/3 + 29(1)^{2}/2 - 20(1)))\\
&= 2\pi(64 -640/3 + 29(8) - 80 - (1/4 -10/3 + 29/2 - 20))\\
&= 45\pi/2
\end{align}
</math>
statement_html:
Full-Solution Problems. Justify your answers and show all your work. Simplification of answers is not required.

Express the volume of the solid obtained by rotating the bounded region that lies between the curves \(y = (x-2)^{2}\) and \(y=x\) about the vertical line \(x=5\). Do not evaluate this integral.

Simplification of answers is not required.

that lies between the curves $y = (x-2)^{2}$ and $y=x$ about the
vertical line $x=5$. Do not evaluate this integral.
statement_raw:
<b> Full-Solution Problems. Justify your answers and show all your work. Simplification of answers is not required. </b>

Express the volume of the solid obtained by rotating the bounded region that lies between the curves <math> y = (x-2)^{2} </math> and <math> y=x </math> about the vertical line <math> x=5 </math>. Do not evaluate this integral.
